Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2008 04:22PM peapot wrote: I showered 2 days after I came home.  I tied a shoestring around my neck and pinned my drains to it.  The warm water feels so good on the drain incisions and they need stay clean.
Posts.Title: showering with drains HeatherL PhyllisCC

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2008 09:43AM peapot wrote: i know I'm not being scientific here, just telling you how it was with me.  I had a lumpectomy and 8 chemo treatments.  My last treatment was 10/25/07.  My tumor markers were elevated so i decided to have a bilateral mastectomy 1/3/08.  As I have recovered from the biggest surgery I've ever had, I couldn't imagine facing chemo now.  It was so much easier to have chemo first and have time to decide what was the best course in terms of a mastectomy.  An oncologist wants to treat it and a surgeon wants to take it out, that's their jobs, you have to decide and you can trust your gut to make the right move. It sounds like you've got the smarts to do that. Good luck with your decision.  Mary
Posts.Title: Is My Surgeon Nuts, Or Did You Hear This Too???? one2beamup Panchoandlefty

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2008 03:24PM peapot wrote: Smart girl to take care of your hair.  Mine fell out on day 17. my children had cut it close to my head (they enjoyed it at least) my last treatment was 10/25 and i have just enough to cover my head now.  I wish you the best!!
Posts.Title: Is My Surgeon Nuts, Or Did You Hear This Too???? one2beamup Panchoandlefty

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2008 06:42PM peapot wrote: ailenroc, I think I  get it, My treament was last year (lumpectomy chemo)then I had prophylactic bilateral in January, so it's pretty much behind me, except that I get nervous sick when i have to have a blood test, and I miss my breasts every day, and sometimes i wonder if the cancer is still lurking somewhere, but to look at me one never knows it and my family is so glad i can do for them that they forget what I've been through,  I really want life to seem normal but i never want to forget what I've been through and how strong i was to get through it (stronger than i ever thought I could be) and how proud i am of what I went through and how grateful I am that I'm healthy> i can only think that its a different normal and that we get used to the new normal.  I wish you love and luck. Mary
Posts.Title: I'm not depressed ... just sad ailenroc ailenroc

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2008 03:32PM peapot wrote: i had reconstruction this year  and the alloderm cost was initially rejected by my insur co.  I was surprised because they have covered every test imaginable!!  I spoke to my PS and he said the co. had set up a special unit just to help with insur issues.  I never heard back and everything was covered.  I wish you all luck with it.  I know bills and insur are the last thing we need to be concerned about. mary

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2008 10:41PM peapot wrote: I also had an elevator ride but when I got downstairs to the OR my preacher was waiting outside for me, the look on his face was priceless when he saw the wire hanging out of me.  It's been a year and I just remembered that reading your posts.  I felt really bad for him then but I kind of chuckled tonight thinking about it.  What a difference a year makes!!
Posts.Title: breast surgery fuzzypeach CAZ

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2008 08:11PM peapot wrote: My surgeon told me that she would make another incision to remove mine when I had my mastectomy but she must have gone thru my mastectomy incision because I didn't have any other incision.  I didn't even miss it and usually forget it was ever there.  Is that any help?  My other BC friends have said it was no big deal for them either.  Congratulations for having it behind you!!!
Posts.Title: Port Removal Questions Ggma Ggma

Posts.Content: peapot wrote: I finished chemo in Oct 2007 and had my first period since then 3 weeks ago AND IT HASN"T STOPPED YET!  It was on and off on and off until yesterday when I really thought I was losing pints.  I went to the gyn today and he told me that my hormones were getting back to work but my ovaries weren't sure what was going on.  He put me on Progesterone for 5 days and then off to help regulate it.  We will see what happens.  I had heard that the first cycle could be a bear but I had no idea.  I'm 42 and silly me thought I had been through menopause and was done with it all.  Hadn't read any posts about this so I thought I would enlighten everyone. Dx 5/30/2007, IDC, 1cm, Stage IB, Grade 3, 1/20 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: My first menstrual cycle after chemo peapot peapot

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2008 08:23PM peapot wrote: i had my surgery 1/3 and had 3 drains for a week and the 4th for 10 days.  My breast where that drain was swelled so much my skin was shiny, so I went back and he took fluid off with a needle.  It sounds awful but it didn't hurt at all and I was much more comfortable afterwards, I had worked myself up over nothing.  The place where that 4th drain was still hurts a lot but no signs of infection so I guess its the fluid.  Having my 2nd fill Friday and looking forward to it.
Posts.Title: 3 days post bilat with recon twogirls twogirls

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2008 05:59PM peapot wrote: I had 8 chemo treatments.  I had a port put in my chest 2 days before my 1st treatment.  It was 1/2 hour surgery and very worth it to me.  They sprayed something on it to freeze everytime I had a treatment so I never felt a thing.  By the end of chemo my veins were so tough that i couldn't imagine someone being able to find one that would work.  I also saw one woman in there with me who didn't have a port and the nurse had a terrible time getting it in her vein.  I called it my third boob because it wasn't flush against my skin, but it was worth it.  Good Luck.
Posts.Title: chemo or no chemo sonnebe peapot
